channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Math Scores Fell in Nearly Every State, and Reading Dipped on National Exam
item.description: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a single state was able to improve test scores for math.

item.title: Bring Back Competitive Admissions? Some NYC Middle Schools May Not.
item.description: After a pandemic moratorium, city leaders are letting school superintendents decide whether to bring back some admissions requirements that critics say feed racial disparities.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York City schools chancellor, David C. Banks, said he would allow middle schools to resume using selective admissions, but many may not.

item.title: In Tim Ryan’s Ohio Senate Race, the D Is Often Silent
item.description: Mr. Ryan, the Ohio Democrat who is challenging J.D. Vance, has turned the state into perhaps the country’s unlikeliest Senate battleground.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Gaelen Morse for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tim Ryan is in contention in a state that Donald Trump twice carried by eight points and Democrats had effectively written off.

item.title: Fears Over Fate of Democracy Leave Many Voters Frustrated and Resigned
item.description: As democracy frays around them, Republicans and Democrats see different culprits and different risks.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Liam James Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allyse Barba speaking with Mandela Barnes, the Democratic candidate for the Senate from Wisconsin, at an event in La Crosse. Ms. Barba does not believe voting will make a difference in Wisconsin.

item.title: Tom Brady and Ron DeSantis Are Said to Be on Texting Terms
item.description: The Republican nominee for Wisconsin governor, Tim Michels, told supporters recently that while DeSantis was watching a Packers game at Lambeau Field, he was texting the Buccaneers quarterback.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Julio Aguilar/Getty Images and Phelan M. Ebenhack/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tim Michels, the Republican candidate for governor in Wisconsin, played host to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida at a recent Packers game. Mr. Michels said: “I say, ‘Who are you texting with?’ He says, ‘I’m texting with Tom Brady.’”

item.title: Lindsey Graham and the ‘Speech or Debate’ Clause, Explained
item.description: The senator, seeking to avoid testifying in a Georgia inquiry into election interference, has appealed to the Supreme Court. But what exactly is the clause behind his argument?
item.dc:creator: Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, has argued that the Constitution shields him from having to face a grand jury’s questions.

item.title: Their America Is Vanishing. Like Trump, They Insist They Were Cheated.
item.description: The white majority is fading, the economy is changing and there’s a pervasive sense of loss in districts where Republicans fought the outcome of the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller and David D. Kirkpatrick
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Richmond, Texas.

item.title: The One Where Matthew Perry Writes an Addiction Memoir
item.description: In “Friends, Lovers and the Big Terrible Thing,” the actor gets serious about sobriety, mortality, colostomy bags and pickleball.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.category: Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing (Book)
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: By the time he was 49, Matthew Perry writes in his new book, he had spent more than half of his life in treatment centers or sober living facilities.

item.title: A Lonely Protest in Beijing Inspires Young Chinese to Find Their Voice
item.description: As beginner dissenters, they’re timid and scared. But they are experiencing a quiet political awakening, unhappy about censorship, repression and “zero Covid.”
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Xi Jinping Now Holds Near-Absolute Power in China, Creating Risks
item.description: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, left, with new members of the Politburo Standing Committee at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: China G.D.P. Data Is Unexpectedly Released After Delay
item.description: China said its economy grew 3.9 percent in the third quarter. But investors unnerved by Xi Jinping’s power grab — and his state-heavy agenda — sent Chinese shares tumbling.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Beijing vegetable market last month. China on Monday reported a modest rebound in economic activity for the quarter ending in September.

item.title: Cultural Bereavement: Naming the Grief Refugees May Feel
item.description: There is a name for the specific type of grief that both refugees and migrants experience. It’s called “cultural bereavement.”
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Theo Stroomer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tamara Plieshkova reunited with her granddaughter in Colorado after escaping the war in Ukraine in September.

item.title: ALCS: Yankees Season Ends as Astros Head to World Series
item.description: The gap between the American League’s two best teams proved awfully wide, with Houston heading to the World Series as the Yankees wonder what went wrong.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Houston Astros are the third team to sweep a division series and a league championship series in the same season. The others were the 2014 Kansas City Royal and the 2007 Colorado Rockies.

item.title: NLCS: Bryce Harper Is Building His Legacy With Phillies
item.description: Harper’s two-run home run in the eighth inning gave this city something few expected: the 2022 N.L. pennant.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Tim Nwachukwu/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bryce Harper was a phenom as a teenager, and signed a $330 million deal with Philadelphia in 2019. He is delivering on all expectations.

item.title: This Wasn’t the Vibe Shift Democrats Had in Mind
item.description: Republicans are threatening to peak at exactly the wrong moment for Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kari Lake appears to be on a roll in Arizona.

item.title: Biden and Trump Share One Thing
item.description: They may be the two weakest presidents since before the progressive era.
item.dc:creator: Yuval Levin
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photographs by Glowimages, maximkabb, and wilatlak villette via Getty

item.title: The Way Los Angeles Is Trying to Solve Homelessness Is ‘Absolutely Insane’
item.description: Developing affordable housing projects shouldn’t make a miserable existence for those who’ve devoted their lives to it.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Dean, near an encampment in the parking lot where the Venice Dell Community project may be built in Los Angeles. Mr. Dean is homeless and has been living in a tent in the parking lot for more than three months.

item.title: We May Have Only a Few Months to Prevent the Next Pandemic
item.description: The window to act is closing fast.
item.dc:creator: Craig Spencer

item.title: Why America Can’t Do Much About the OPEC Oil Cuts
item.description: Washington sees OPEC Plus’s decision to cut oil production as support for Russia, but Saudi Arabia had legitimate economic reasons for pushing it.
item.dc:creator: Ellen R. Wald
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters
item.media:description: On Oct. 5, a group of oil producers led by Saudi Arabia decided to cut oil production quotas by two million barrels per day starting in November.

item.title: Kari Ann Lake’s Hijacking of Martin Luther King
item.description: Like Donald Trump, she is invoking the civil rights icon in self-serving ways.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: The Three Blunders of Joe Biden
item.description: How the Biden White House has contributed to the Democratic Party’s midterm troubles.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

item.title: A Republican Advantage
item.description: As headlines shift in the weeks before the midterms, so do voters’ top concerns.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Running an Election in the Heart of Election Denialism
item.description: A conversation with Stephen Richer, the chief election officer in Maricopa County, Ariz.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Nina Feldman, Mike Benoist, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Michael Chow/The Arizona Republic, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stephen Richer is the top election official in Maricopa Country, Ariz. Many of the voters in the state doubt the legitimacy of the electoral process.

item.title: Has Polling Broken Politics?
item.description: As the midterms near, Margie Omero and Nate Silver consider what voter surveys are good for.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Facing Surgery? Here’s How to Prepare.
item.description: The best way to navigate a surgery recommendation is to ask a lot of questions.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Trump Organization’s Tax Fraud Trial to Begin on Monday
item.description: The Trump Organization’s trial on tax fraud and other charges begins Monday in Manhattan, raising questions about the future of the former president’s family business.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jury selection in the trial of former president Donald J. Trump’s family begins on Monday.

item.title: What to Know About Harvey Weinstein’s Los Angeles Trial
item.description: The former Hollywood producer was convicted in New York in 2020 of rape and criminal sexual assault. He faces 11 separate charges in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Lauren Herstik
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Etienne Laurent/Getty Image
item.media:description: Former film producer Harvey Weinstein appears in court at the Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on October 4, 2022 in Los Angeles, California.

item.title: Starbucks Showdown in Boston Points to New Phase of Union Campaign
item.description: The company moved to contain the labor push after it took off nationally. Now, with strikes and other tactics, organizers seek to regain momentum.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Workers at a Starbucks in Boston were on strike for more than two months this summer.

item.title: U.S. Executives Are Flocking to Saudi Davos in the Desert
item.description: Some top American business leaders are headed to the Saudi business conference. But Biden administration officials, angry over the kingdom’s stance on oil production and ties with Russia, are staying away.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guests arriving in 2019 for the Future Investment Initiative conference, nicknamed “Davos in the Desert,” in the Saudi capital, Riyadh.

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Break a Phone Addiction
item.description: Whether smartphone overuse constitutes a true addiction is still up for debate, but experts say there are ways to scale down.
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Brunswick Stew Is the Perfect Soup for Right Now
item.description: Soul-warming, savory and sweet, this dish with a deep history is perfect for right now.
item.dc:creator: Eric Kim
item.media:credit: Jennifer Chase for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicken is most commonly used today, though some stew experts throw in beef chuck or pork shoulder for flavor and fat.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
